fault_injector.injector module

class fault_injector.injector.FaultInjection(values, start=None, stop=None, increasing=0)[source]

Bases: object

A class for injecting various faults into a numeric time-series or sensor data.

This class allows simulation of real-world sensor anomalies including drift, offset, noise, missing data, and stuck readings. Faults can be applied over a specified range of indices.

Parameters:

valueslist of float or int

The original numeric values to inject faults into.

startint or ‘random’, optional

Start index of the fault (default 0). If ‘random’, a random start is selected.

stopint or ‘random’, optional

Stop index of the fault (default: length of values). Must be greater than start.

increasingint (0 or 1), optional

Determines fault direction: 1 = increase values, 0 = decrease values (default 0).

Supported Fault Types

  1. Drift: Linear change over time

  2. Offset: Constant bias added to the values

  3. Gaussian Noise: Random noise with normal distribution

  4. Uniform Noise: Random noise with uniform distribution

  5. NaN: Replace values with missing data

  6. Stuck Value: Replace values with a constant

Notes

  • Faults are applied over the range [start, stop).

  • The class preserves the original values for comparison.

  • Useful for testing robustness of sensor data processing algorithms, anomaly detection, and fault-tolerant systems.

restore_values()[source]

This will revert values back to the original state

inject_fault(change_lst)[source]

This is a generic method that can be used to add custom faults to the original values. It takes in a list of numeric values that will be added to the existing values. For example, this method is used by the inject_drift method to add the drift values to the existing values.

Note: this method is used to add values to the existing values not replace the existing values.

Parameters:

change_lst (list) – a list of numeric values

inject_drift(drift_rate=None)[source]

Injects a linear drift into the signal over the fault range.

Parameters:

drift_ratefloat, optional

The rate of change per step. If not provided, a random small value is generated as:

\[\text{drift_rate} = U(0, 0.0001) \times d \times \bar{x}\]
where:

  • \(U(a,b)\) is a uniform random number in [a, b]

  • \(d\) is the fault direction (+1 for increasing, -1 for decreasing)

  • \(\bar{x}\) is the mean of the original values

Math behind Drift Fault

The drift increases (or decreases) linearly with time:

\[y_i = x_i + (i - s) \cdot \text{drift_rate}, \quad i \in [s, e)\]
where:

  • \(x_i\) = original value

  • \(y_i\) = value after drift

  • \(s\) = start index

  • \(e\) = stop index

Impact on Descriptive Statistics (within [s, e))

  • Mean:

The mean of the faulted segment increases (or decreases) linearly by half the total drift span:

\[\bar{y}_{[s,e)} = \bar{x}_{[s,e)} + \frac{(e - s - 1)}{2} \cdot \text{drift_rate}\]

  • Variance:

The added linear trend increases variance quadratically with the fault length:

\[\text{Var}(y_{[s,e)}) = \text{Var}(x_{[s,e)}) + \frac{(e - s)^2 - 1}{12} \cdot \text{drift_rate}^2\]
inject_offset(offset_rate=None)[source]

Injects a constant offset (bias) into the signal over the specified fault range.

Parameters:

offset_ratefloat, optional

Fraction of the mean value to use as the offset magnitude. If not provided, a random offset is generated:

\[\text{offset_rate} \sim U(0.01, 0.1)\]

The actual offset value is computed as:

\[\text{offset_value} = \bar{x} \cdot \text{offset_rate}\]
where:

  • \(U(a,b)\) is a uniform random value in [a, b]

  • \(\bar{x}\) is the mean of the original (fault-free) values

Math behind Offset Fault

The offset fault adds a constant bias to all values between the fault start and stop indices:

\[\begin{split}y_i = \begin{cases} x_i + \text{offset_value}, & \text{if } s \le i < e \\ x_i, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}\end{split}\]
where:

  • \(x_i\) = original value

  • \(y_i\) = value after offset fault

  • \(s\) = start index

  • \(e\) = stop index

Impact on Descriptive Statistics (within [s, e))

  • Mean:

The mean shifts by the offset magnitude:

\[\bar{y}_{[s,e)} = \bar{x}_{[s,e)} + \text{offset_value}\]

  • Variance:

Variance remains unchanged since a constant shift does not alter spread:

\[\text{Var}(y_{[s,e)}) = \text{Var}(x_{[s,e)})\]

The offset direction depends on the increasing flag provided at initialization. If increasing=1, the offset is positive; if increasing=0, the offset is negative.

Notes

Offset faults model sensor bias or systematic calibration error, where readings remain accurate in trend but are consistently higher or lower than true values.

inject_nan()[source]

Replaces all values within the fault range with NaN (Not a Number).

This simulates data loss, sensor dropout, or transmission failure, where no valid measurement is available for a period of time.

Math behind Nan Fault

All values between the fault start and stop indices are set to NaN:

\[\begin{split}y_i = \begin{cases} \text{NaN}, & \text{if } s \le i < e \\ x_i, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}\end{split}\]
where:

  • \(x_i\) = original value

  • \(y_i\) = value after fault injection

  • \(s\) = start index

  • \(e\) = stop index

Impact on Descriptive Statistics (within [s, e))

  • Mean / Variance:

Undefined within the faulted region because all values are NaN. In most statistical analyses, these samples are excluded, effectively reducing the sample size.

Notes

This fault type is commonly used to simulate missing data segments in time series or sensor readings due to disconnection, corruption, or transmission errors.

inject_stuck_value(stuck_val=None)[source]

Replaces all values within the fault range with a constant “stuck” value.

This simulates a sensor fault where the output remains frozen at a fixed reading, regardless of the true input signal.

Parameters:

stuck_valfloat, optional

The constant value to use during the fault period. If not provided, a random stuck value is generated as:

\[\text{stuck_val} = \bar{x} + d \cdot U(0.01, 0.1) \cdot \bar{x}\]
where:

  • \(U(a,b)\) is a uniform random number in [a, b]

  • \(d\) is the fault direction (+1 for increasing, -1 for decreasing)

  • \(\bar{x}\) is the mean of the original values

Math behind Stuck Value Fault

All values between the fault start and stop indices are replaced by a single constant:

\[\begin{split}y_i = \begin{cases} c, & \text{if } s \le i < e \\ x_i, & \text{otherwise} \end{cases}\end{split}\]
where:

  • \(x_i\) = original value

  • \(y_i\) = value after fault injection

  • \(c\) = stuck value

  • \(s\) = start index

  • \(e\) = stop index

Impact on Descriptive Statistics (within [s, e))

  • Mean:

The mean becomes equal to the stuck constant:

\[\bar{y}_{[s,e)} = c\]

  • Variance:

All values are identical, so variance collapses to zero:

\[\text{Var}(y_{[s,e)}) = 0\]

Notes

This fault type is useful for modeling sensor freezing, where a device stops updating and continuously outputs the same measurement.

inject_noise(noise_type, params=None)[source]

Injects random noise into the signal over the fault range.

This simulates measurement noise or sensor variability, and supports two types of noise distributions: Gaussian (normal) and Uniform.

Parameters:

noise_typestr

Type of noise to inject. Must be either "gaussian" or "uniform".

paramslist, optional

Parameters defining the noise distribution.

  • Gaussian: [mu, sigma]

    • mu = mean of the noise (default: 0)

    • sigma = standard deviation (default: std of values[start:stop])

  • Uniform: [low, high]

    • low = lower bound (default: -std of values[start:stop])

    • high = upper bound (default: std of values[start:stop])

Math behind Noise Fault

The values are perturbed by random noise:

  • Gaussian noise:

\[y_i = x_i + \epsilon_i, \quad \epsilon_i \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma^2), \quad i \in [s, e)\]

  • Uniform noise:

\[y_i = x_i + \epsilon_i, \quad \epsilon_i \sim U(a, b), \quad i \in [s, e)\]
where:

  • \(x_i\) = original value

  • \(y_i\) = value after noise injection

  • \(s\) = start index

  • \(e\) = stop index

  • \(\mathcal{N}(\mu, \sigma^2)\) = normal distribution

  • \(U(a, b)\) = uniform distribution in [a, b]

Gausian Noise Fault: Impact on Descriptive Statistics (within [s, e))

  • Mean:

Expected mean remains approximately unchanged if \(\mu = 0\):

\[\mathbb{E}[\bar{y}_{[s,e)}] = \bar{x}_{[s,e)} + \mu\]

  • Variance:

Total variance increases additively by noise variance:

\[\text{Var}(y_{[s,e)}) = \text{Var}(x_{[s,e)}) + \sigma^2\]

Uniform Noise Fault: Impact on Descriptive Statistics (within [s, e))

  • Mean:

Expected mean shifts by the midpoint of the uniform range:

\[\mathbb{E}[\bar{y}_{[s,e)}] = \bar{x}_{[s,e)} + \frac{a + b}{2}\]

  • Variance:

Variance increases by the variance of the uniform noise:

\[\text{Var}(y_{[s,e)}) = \text{Var}(x_{[s,e)}) + \frac{(b - a)^2}{12}.\]

Variance increases by the variance of the uniform noise.

—

Notes

This fault type is useful for simulating sensor variability, environmental interference, or random jitter in measurements.

plot_compare_values()[source]

This method can be used to plot the injected fault and compare it to the original data
